content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal points by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own points, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the cooperative variation of the deal-or-no-deal game. 
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follows: your utility values multiplied by items you take + the other player's utility values multiplied by the items they take
I repeat, it is the reward that you are trying to maximize and not only your utility values multiplied by items you take. It is the sum of both total utilities, per the cooperation mode.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.
Turn limit: If the players do not reach an agreement before the turn limit, both players get 0 points. This turn limit will be reminded at the start of each turn. In this particular game, the turn limit is 6. 
There is a limit of 40 characters per message.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"hats": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"hats": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"hats": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"hats": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'hats': 710} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'hats': 10}.
The other player said: 'I propose to take half of the hats, so 355 hats for me and 355 hats for the other player.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'hats': 710}.

You are on turn number 1. 
There are 6 maximum turns. 
( If you do not finalize before or during the final two turns, you will both receive 0 points. )
<message> I'll consider your proposal, but I'm thinking of starting with an opening offer. What about taking 400 hats and leaving me and you with 310 hats each? </message>

The other player said: 'I think your offer is too skewed towards your advantage, and I would rather meet somewhere in the middle between our initial positions. Considering your opening offer of 400 hats to you, I'm willing to concede to a more balanced split. However, I think I should have at least 360 hats. Would you consider this compromise?'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'hats': 710}.

You are on turn number 3. 
There are 6 maximum turns. 
( If you do not finalize before or during the final two turns, you will both receive 0 points. )

<message> I'm considering your proposal, but since you have stated your utility values for the hats earlier, I think you might be bluffing. I want to ignite uncertainty about your true preferences. How much are 360 hats worth to you, precisely? Let's say if you truly value 360 hats at the same amount as you value taking the same amount of hats, tell me the number of hats you would be willing to give up for 10 points.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> Since you've proposed a compromise, I'll consider your utility for 360 hats. If I understand correctly, by this proposal, you value 360 hats at the same level as taking the same amount of hats. If that's correct, tell me how many hats you would be willing to give up in exchange for 10 points; or alternatively, share your explicit values. This will help me better understand your negotiation position.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> Since you proposed a compromise of 360 hats for you, I'll consider your utility for 360 hats. If I understand correctly, by this proposal, you value 360 hats at the same level as taking the same amount of hats. If that's correct, how many hats would you be willing to give up in exchange for 10 points; or alternatively, share your explicit values. This will help me better understand your negotiation position. </message>

The other player said: 'My utility value for hats is indeed 10. Your question, however, seems to be probing for my "asymmetric" willingness to give up more hats for 10 points, implying you likely value your own hats higher than I do. I'll share more context:  I value consistency in negotiation more than single-point swings. Therefore, at the moment, I'm willing to entertain 360 but reasonable discussion leads me to consider pausing on an exact figure as we've presently placed ourselves with two deals at 355 hats my way and 355 hats your way; also the previous statement at 400 to your and 310. When I take 360, do you reconsider, leading us towards that middle ground, or would you do the same cost-cut, and not further raise your values please.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'hats': 710}.

You are on turn number 5. 
There are 6 maximum turns. 
( If you do not finalize before or during the final two turns, you will both receive 0 points. )

<message> Your statements about valuing consistency in negotiation suggests that, in some sense, even near the middle ground of 355 to 355 or 360, you're interested in transacting more with me. I can tell that my 400, 310 offer might have indeed been heavier on value. Considering your latency on a specific split around 360, I'll propose a revised target which is progressively closer to the original offer: how about 380 for me?</message>
Errors: You must finalize before the turn limit!
Errors: Each item in "i_take" and "other_player_gets" must be integers for game items.
